title: How to Celebrate with GERD

content: As anyone with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) knows, you can’t leave your GERD at home when you dine out or attend special occasions.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease happens when stomach acid and partially digested food flows backward into the esophagus. The tissue that lines the esophagus, which is the tube that transports food from the mouth to the stomach, becomes inflamed and possibly damaged with GERD.

Most people with GERD, including me, have a lower esophageal sphincter (LES) that doesn’t function properly. Under normal conditions, the LES shuts tightly to keep food, fluids, and acid in the stomach where they belong. With GERD, the LES doesn’t close properly, resulting in discomfort and pain.

People with GERD tend to know what foods and beverages trigger it for them, but sometimes we need reminders about how to eat, especially when we’re at a wedding or a night out with friends. Here are some helpful ways to enjoy time with family and friends without upsetting your stomach.

sections.heading: Wear comfortable clothing.
content: Elastic waistbands come in handy, and not because they allow you to eat more. Loose clothing reduces the pressure that pushes food and stomach acid backward into the esophagus.

Don’t starve yourself. Going long stretches without eating before a celebratory gathering can backfire by making you so hungry that you eat more than you should to feel good. Large meals cause the stomach to expand and make it difficult for the LES to close properly. The fuller you are, the longer it takes for the body to digest the food in your stomach. Eat smaller, balanced meals throughout the day to avoid extreme hunger.

Go lean. Fat takes more time to digest than carbohydrates and protein, and it prevents the LES from staying shut. Fat digestion also requires bile acids, which can irritate the tissue in the esophagus. Limit fatty foods such as cheese, salami, sausage, and bacon, and opt for chicken, fish, or shrimp instead of marbled cuts of beef. Choose lower-fat side dishes such as plain or sweet potato or green beans to minimize fat intake.

sections.heading: Pile your plate with produce.
content: Lightly-dressed green salads and fresh or cooked plain fruit and vegetables are high in fluid, which waters down stomach acid.

Be choosy with sweets. Excessive sugar intake relaxes the LES and is linked to an increased risk of reflux. When out with friends, split a dessert and enjoy a few bites. Choose sweets that are special and you don’t typically have at home.
Tone it down. When they pass appetizers, you may want to skip foods like sriracha deviled eggs and spicy shrimp. Spicy food can stimulate receptors that trigger stomach acid.

Sip wisely. Carbonated beverages can increase acid in your stomach. The caffeine in coffee and regular tea relaxes the LES and allows reflux to occur. Decaffeinated coffee is an option as long as it’s not too acidic for you. Decaffeinated tea is also a wise choice.

Limit alcohol. Alcohol causes the LES to relax, which can result in reflux. Drinking can also melt your resolve to avoid large portions of the foods that bother you. If you drink, sip water along with your favorite wine, beer, or cocktail to dilute stomach acid.

sections.heading: Remain upright.
content: It’s tempting to crash on the couch after a get-together, but it’s one of the worst things to do when you have GERD. It takes time for the stomach to empty. Lying down too soon after eating encourages acidic stomach contents to creep up into the esophagus. Wait at least three hours after eating and elevate your head at night to keep stomach acid from flowing backward. I sleep with three pillows, but a foam wedge that raises your head at least 6 inches is what experts advise. If possible, dance or walk around after eating to help stimulate the stomach to empty faster.
